thread.title: Plenty of flavors to be found at Taste of Springfield
thread.title_full: Plenty of flavors to be found at Taste of Springfield

title: Plenty of flavors to be found at Taste of Springfield
text:
Plenty of flavors to be found at Taste of Springfield Jan Peterson 6:45 p.m. CDT September 30, 2015 Buy Photo Jeff Schrag taps the ceremonial first keg of Octoberfest Village during last year’s Taste of Springfield on Park Central Square. (Photo: News-Leader file photo) Buy Photo CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Each year, the Taste of Springfield celebration tends to grow. 
Anywhere from 15 to 20 restaurants will be represented at this ninth annual event, which also includes OktoberFest Village, where a variety of beers are available for sampling, and the brand-new Taste of Gameday, to be held on Park Central East. 
Sarah Hough, community event coordinator for Downtown Springfield Association, says a number of new restaurants are joining this year’s lineup, including Black Sheep, a new Jalili family restaurant that will offer gourmet burgers, and Lindberg’s Bar, which recently opened a kitchen and offers the house specialty Cashew Chicken Poutine. 
“His description was heavenly,” Hough says. “When you put it on a bed of french fries and add some cheese and all kinds of good stuff, people will love it,” she says. 
Other first-timers include Artisans Oven and Fork and Spoon. 
“And all of the award-winners will be returning and defending their title there,” Hough says. 
Returning are: 
• That Lebanese Place, 2014 Best Appetizer winner for falafel and hummus 
• Café Cusco, 2014 Best Entrée winner for black bean quinoa sliders 
• The Cub, 2014 Best Dessert Winner for pumpkin harvest cupcake 
• Dublin’s Pass, 2014 Best Booth winner 
In addition to sampling food and voting on favorites, folks can enjoy live music from 11:30 a.m. through 9 p.m. and participate in the first Taste of Gameday, which kicks off one hour earlier, at 10 a.m. 
Brett Johnston, communication manager for Downtown Springfield Association, says, “It is in essence almost like a pep rally for Missouri State football. We’re going to do ESPN’s Game Day downtown-style,” he says. 
Hough says the decision to add Taste of Gameday came about as organizers were trying to figure out a way to unite the festivities going on at Bearfest Village with Taste of Springfield. 
Taste of Gameday will feature a panel of guests that includes MSU President Clif Smart, MSU alum/football pro Dennis Heim, television legend Ned Reynolds, Art Hains, the voice of the Bears and more. Taste of Gameday will also feature live music from Jonathan Joseph and Soul Society, giveaways and more. 
“It will get things started for a busy day downtown,” Johnston says. “We hope that it will encourage some cross traffic from our events and Bearfest Village. I think there’s enough time for people to enjoy both.” 
Want to go? 
• What: The 9th Annual Taste of Springfield featuring OktoberFest Village and Taste of Gameday 
• When: Saturday; food available 11 a.m.-3 p.m.; beer, 11 a.m.-9 p.m.; live music, 11:30 a.m.-9 p.m. Taste of Gameday kicks off one hour earlier, at 10 a.m., on Park Central East 
• Where: Downtown Springfield 
• Cost: Free; tickets to sample food are 10 for $10 (each sample requires two or three tickets); beer tickets sold separately 
• Info: www.itsalldowntown.com or 417-831-6200 
• 11:30 a.m.-1 p.m.: Dart Frog 
• 1:30 p.m.-3:30 p.m.: Brookline Station 
• 4-5 p.m.: Cory Jay 
• 5:30-7 p.m.: Justice Adams Band 
• 7:30-9 p.m.: Jesse and the Rips
